DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: RADI, P. A.;GONÇALVES, P. A. R.;Radi, Polyana Alves;GONÇALVES, POLYANA ALVES RADI;Radi, Polyana A.;RADI, POLYANA A

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: DOUTORA e MESTRE em engenharia de materiais com trabalhos na área de tribologia de materiais carbonosos e triboquímica analítica em filmes de DLC (Diamond-Like Carbon) para aplicação espacial, biomédica e da industrial em geral. BACHAREL EM QUÍMICA pela Universidade Federal de Uberlândia (2004) com LICENCIATURA PLENA EM QUÍMICA pela Universidade Federal de Uberlândia (2004). Durante a graduação realizou pesquisas na área de Química, principalmente nos seguintes temas: Produtos naturais, alelopatia, CdO, nanocristais, herbicida natural, pontos quânticos e síntese de polímeros. Experiência em diversos equipamentos de análise química e/ou mecânica tais como: IR, tribometro, micro e nano - durômetro, HPLC, CG, Absorção atômica, Raman, MEV, FEG entre outros.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: PHD and master's degree in materials engineering with works in the field of Tribology of carbon based materials and analytical in tribochemistry in DLC (Diamond-Like Carbon) for space, biomedicine and other industrial application. BACHELOR'S DEGREE in chemistry from the Federal University of Uberlândia (2004) and licensed FULL in CHEMISTRY at the Federal University of Uberlândia (2004). During graduation he conducted research in the Chemical area, mainly in the following themes: natural products, Allelopathy, CdO, nanocrystals, natural herbicide, quantum dots and synthesis of polymers. Experience in various chemical and / or mechanical analysis such as: IR, tribometro, micro and nano - durometer, HPLC, CG, atomic absorption, Raman, SEM, FEG and others.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Friction and wear maps of titanium alloy against a-C:H20% (DLC) film

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-1.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Materiais e Processos para Engenharia Aeronáutica e Aeroespacial

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Understanding the mechanismthat control friction andwear is a complex and sometimes difficult task. There is a general recognition that these parameters are strongly dependent on load, sliding speed, temperature, time, contact geometry, surface roughness, ambient atmosphere andmaterial surface compositions. Friction and wear mapsmay be away to estimate friction andwear behavior overwide load and speed ranges. Additionally, they can be used as material selection guides, as well as design guides for different engineering applications. Despite the many attractive properties of DLC (diamond-like carbon) films, there are no maps available for DLC films. To date, on the web scientific search site there are only articles with dimensional wear maps for ceramic materials. This paper presents the wear rate map for DLC film with 20% hydrogen content (a-C:H20%) using a titanium alloy (Ti6Al4V) ball as counter body. Hardness, Raman scattering, and stressmeasurementswere used to prove DLC film quality. Then, by using the results fromthe friction andwear tests it presents friction and ballwear volume maps as two new evaluations tools which better project the tribological relations between material behavior, load and speed. These maps successfully highlighted abrupt shifts in DLC material behavior, thus bypassingmany hours of tests. Once more DLCmaps are available, DLC filmswill becomemore economically viable for use in industry and space.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: DLC film properties obtained by a low cost and modified pulsed-DC discharge
A tribological study of the hybrid lubrication of DLC films with oil and water

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This paper reports on the results of a tribological study that compared the friction coefficient and wear volume of titanium alloy (Ti6Al4V) and 316L stainless steel samples, with and without DLC films, in contact with humidity, water and oils. Distilled water (DW), and synthetic motor oil (SO) were applied to some of the sample surfaces, while others were left uncoated or coated only with DLC. The DLC films were grown by using a Pulsed DC Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition (PE-CVD) technique. The friction coefficient and wear volume of various sample pairs were studied as a function of applied load with constant sliding speed, using sphere-on-flat configuration in the reciprocating mode. The sphere wear was measured using a very small pin approach, in agreement with the ASTM G99 norm. Also, the film?s atomic arrangements and graphitization level before and after tribotests were analyzed by Raman scattering spectroscopy. Tribotests showed that the friction coefficient and the wear depend on boundary lubrication, suggesting that the chemistry of the fluid lubricant is an important parameter to be considered. Results showed that the lowest friction coefficient and nowearwere obtained to DLC/DLC pair in contact with synthetic oil. The most significant aspect of our work is that with just one friction surface with DLC film it is possible to obtain a 56% reduction in the friction coefficients and no measurable wear, resulting in a 50% reduction in production cost.
